bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, December 14, 1922

div1.p: Connor reports on yellow fever in Mexico. He suspects a Caribbean epidemic spreading from Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, December 14, 1922
div1.opener:
I. H. B
Connor
125 Dunning Avenue.
San Antonio, Texas.
December 14th., 1922
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your welcome letter of December 5th., with enclosures
reached me yesterday. I am planning on returning to Mexico soon after
Xmas and will probably leave here for that country on the 27th., inst.,
and therefore will not have the pleasure of seeing you this year.

You speak of the out-break in Panuco. The infection
had undoubtedly been present in that city (10,000 inhabitants) for
months before we recognized it, the diagnosis having been that of malaria
with hemmorhages or pernicious malaria, and from here? it extended
to Tampico and then along the line of the railroad to Ciudad
Victoria and possibly other places. Tuxpam later reported a case and
reports had it, that in the Huastecas there had been cases amongst
the soldiers.

Lyster shaped our campaign on the plan of guarding
the key centers and depending on the smaller places cleaing them-
selves. I think Lyster must have have arrived at this conclusion without
the benefits of a through preliminary survey of the area
and without a study of the vital statistics of the 'steg' infested
zone. LePrince nor Caldwell considered Panuco as a place in which
anti-larvae measures should be applied. Caldwell told me that he re-
comended going into Panuco but that Lyster would not approve of
same. When I took over that area in January (1922) there had been no
case of yellow fever reported in Tampico for one year and on July
1st of the present year I thought the index had been low
enough for a long enough period to warrant turning over the zone to
the local authorities with a trained force of men to carry on, Dr.
White reviewed the city of Tampico with Monroe and approved of the
transfer to the local men.

Before we made this transfer a report of
hemmorhagic malaria was announced in Panuco. Dr. White order Monroe to
investigate (Dr. White was in Mexico City at the time, while I was in
Vera Cruz) Monroe reported that he could no evidence of pernicous
nor hemmorhagic malaria nor malaria and here the matter ended, the
process of transfer to the local authorities was concluded by Monroe
on June 30th. and he later came North.

Dr. White and I were at this time on the west
coast inspecting Colima, Mazatlan and other places. On our return to
Mexico City, late in July, came the announcement of a case of yellow
fever originating in Panuco and dying in the Tampico Hosp.

We hesitated to accept the clinical diagnosis and held off until an
examination of tissues could be made which was later done by
Dr. Perrin and confirmed as yellow fever. As soon as the announce-
ment was made, that is the clinical diagnosis, men were placed at
work reducing the stegomyiae in Panuco and surrounding country.

In due time and according to schedule undoubted cases of y.f. began
to appear in Panuco and about the same time in Tampico and the
epidemic was on.

Later in conversation with Dr. White he stated that it appeared
that the infection had been present in Tampico all the while and
was endemic, being kept alive thru the children in a certain area
of Tampico. I have been loath to accept this thought because if
true there would have been some well marked cases in the course
of eighteen months which is the period that no cases were reported,
it seems to be to be quite unusuall to expect that the infection
could have laid dormant for so long a period when there are
large numbers of non-immunes in the city and a large number arrivng
every day, many of whom lived in the distrcits in which Dr. Scannell
later found cases, and had been living in the same district for
many months.

The case aboard the Schooner William E. Burnham which arrived at
Mobile September 14 1922 has caused Dr. White to think that perhaps
the infection may have been introduced into Panuco from the
Dutch Guiana as one of the oil companies had been receiving men from
the oil fields of Dutch Guiana and the first cases found in Panuco
were in one of these companies camps.. Dr. White is I believe following up
this clue.

After having made the trip over Mexico in company with Dr. WHite
I am convinced that we have in Mexico a problem the like of
which we have not met with before. Cuba, Panama, Guayaquil and
Peru, the first three places had for all intents and purposes only
one endemic center of infection in each country, Peru was purely
and epidemic proposition and none of the foregoing countries had
good, fast and easy system of intercommunicatios as has Mexico.
In Mexico we ha at three centers of endemicity and the highways
of travel are we so well developed that it is possible to journey
from Yucatan on the Gulf to Mazatlan on the Pacific within the period
of incubation of the disease, this phase of the problem I don't
think we realized at the begining of the campaign, again Mexico is
still in throes of a revolution, that is, conditions are such thatas to
call for constant movement of troops and this troop movement has
been responsible for spreading the infection at times. In brief,
the entire area of Mexico below the 1000 meter above sea-level is
infested with stegomyiae and the area sufficiently popu-
lated to allow the infection to travel around in a circle, if we
pursue the plan of guarding only the key points. The point I wish
3.
to bring out is that if we continue holding only the key centers
and working in towns only when the disease has declared itself that
the campaign will be a prolonged one whereas if we would sweep the
area the length of time of elimination ought to be considerably reduced.

The Mexican officials have given good co-operation and are sincere
in their desires to rid the country of yellow fever, but their or-
ganization is handicapped by not having a sufficient number of
full time officers, this is true all thru the country, not withstanding
this defect they do remarkably well.

I feel that we both, Mexicans and Americans, have gained by association
and perhaps the greatest contribution from us has been the practical
demonstration that co-operation is the elimination of disease is a
practical and economical measure.

Another need in our work is the laboratory to aid us in clearing
up these cases that simulate yellow fever yet respond readily to
quinine, this condition is very confusing to the native and he being
naturally sensitive to ridicule does not wish to announce a case
as yellow fever until there could be no doubt as to the diag-
nosis when of course it would be evident to everyone what the a
ailment wasis.

The Yucatan area is seemingly free of the infection as is Campeche,
but the danger here is from re-infection and theses areas cannot
be left for long in the hands of the local authorities. Merida
will I think will hold a low 'steg' index longer than most places
as the most important breeding places in that city are in the under
ground cisterns (aljibes) and fish one placed therein will remain
until the water is drained from the cistern, but this does not obtain
in other places and further the rainfall is usually greater in the
other cities of Mexico than in Merida therefore there is greater op-
portunity for the re-filling of the water containers. Troop move-
ment for the Peninsula is an impotant important item.

The interior of Tabasco during the present year reported an epi-
demic of malaria with blood vomit and one or two cases we the same
disease were reported from Frontera, one case died and one recovered
under quinine, both cases had vomiting of blood, I am inclined to re-
gard such cases sufficiently suspicious as to warrant a careful survey
at least of the entire area. There is a belief amongst many physicans that
Tabasco at San Juan Bautista, now Villahermosa, was once an en-,lb/> demic focus. It is these cases of benign yellow fever with an obvious
malarial infection superimposed responding to quinine that confuse the
local man and it is right here that the laboratory man can render
great aid.

The African detail as you know has been definitely postponed until
the Mexican situation has cleared up and this will probably mean
a year or so.

The Brazil situation appears to be gathering strength and should it
jump its limits and light up the Carribean litoral we certainly
would a tremendous epidemic. I believe Dr. White has hopes of interest
ing Dr. Chagas in a co-operative campaign for all Brazil and if suc-
cessful it ought to be easy to extend same to the Guianas.

I am hopeful that in the near future a detail will be given me where I can
take my family as Mrs. Connor is not too strong and finds it increas-
ingly difficult to carry on alone. You know we have three youngsters
Grace age 11 whom you saw at Panama, Ruth age 9 and Lucille age 6 all
healthy and full of energy. We came on to San Antonio as the
winters are less severe and it is near enough to Mexico so that
in case of emergency I could reach them within a reasonable time, again
the housing situation in the north has been so acute that we found it
disagreeable and for a time were forced to live in with another
family, while here we have a bungalow plainly furnished and convienent
to some former Isthmian friends, the Osterhouts, whom you will probably
re-call as one time health Officer at Bocas del Toro.

I am enclosing a picture of our youngsters which will give you an idea
of them as they are to-day.

closer.salute:
With sincere good wishes to you and yours,
in which Mrs. Connor joins me, I am,
as ever, your friend.
